Should the car’s occupants be shot at, killed, even if they’re civilians? What if there are children in the car?). Like the other films about Iraq, war atrocity texts are removed from historical and political context. Despite the filmmakers’ best wishes to foster outrage, create mass revulsion in a public apparently immune to the moral aspects of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, the most scathing texts were ignored by American audiences. Only the documentaries (Taxi to the Dark Side, 2007; Standard Operating Procedure, 2008) took up the issues of systemic enemy and civilian abuse, as well as Command’s deliberate policies of torture of both known combatants and innocent citizens. The fictional films don’t address the enemy: Who, after all, were and are the enemies in these two wars? According to the Bush White House, they were “terrorists,” “evil-doers,” “insurgents,” but never soldiers, never human beings with their own coherent belief systems. Denied that status, they could be and were excluded from treatment accorded combatants and prisoners under the Geneva Conventions. Even as President Obama gestured wanly toward closing the American concentration camp at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, the administration refuses to name the prisoners there as soldiers but rather continues to deal with them as “detainees,” or “PUCs” (persons under control). One of the lessons learned from the Vietnam “conflict,” as it was called by the American governments who furthered it, was to deny the enemy legitimacy. If you go to war and declare that you are not at war at all, and are fighting only illegal resisters, then you don’t have to answer for your battlefield conduct in an international court of law or, perhaps more damning, public opinion. Killing a great many civilians will make you unpopular, but that doesn’t necessarily alter the course of your war policy, or the ways in which you determine how the Other is not you. You can show war crimes, and you can also kill discussion: “Atrocities appear with frightening regularity . . . The general tone of the films is despairing, totally the reverse of the loyal and enthusiastic support we see in films made during and about World War II” (Eberwein, 2009, p. 134). If there’s no civilian alignment with the soldiers, then their actions need not represent “us,” viewers who look on appalled. In a paradoxical way, the most extreme films about atrocity give citizens the easiest way to deny the crimes; people must recognize themselves in the soldiers if they are to accept that they, too, might be capable of atrocious behavior. If they can disown the soldiers, they can disavow their actions as well. The further from us soldiers and their actions seem, the easier it is to avoid looking at atrocity since “we” didn’t commit it.

The Bush White House’s attempt to eliminate unpleasant images of wounded and dead during the early years of the two wars may be largely responsible for the outpouring of real and grotesque pictures aired in a number of the films (particularly the slideshow that closes Redacted). When Bush banned photographs of caskets at Dover Air Force Base, he put a premium on war’s reality: the dead. Making the dead vanish created a parade of extraordinarily powerful phantoms (or in director Joe Dante’s clever imaginary, zombies who needed to vote before they could truly die; Homecoming, 2005). Pictures otherwise came from embedded reporters who necessarily surrendered whatever objectivity they could muster, since they were taking images of people who were daily responsible for preserving their lives. The suppression of photos finally ended with the eruption of cheery digital snaps taken by the Military Police of themselves at Abu Ghraib prison (originally Saddam’s own torture palace) featuring, among others, the now infamous Charles Graner and Lynndie England grinning at or with corpses and piles of naked live Iraqis.

There has been a division in the films about Iraq, one that America has seen before in handling problematic wars.11 George Packer, journalist and award-winning author of The Assassin’s Gate (2005), notes with dismay that “all the Iraq-war movies . . . seem entirely atrocity-driven, based on the conceit that combat turns men axiomatically evil and that evil is to be taken as a surrogate for the evil policies that spawned them” (p. 22). Even if one agrees with Packer, the numbers don’t bear out his conclusion. Of the more than 50 films I cover in this analysis, 8 include Americans engaged in some form of torture: Some do the torturing, some are tortured—eight is not “all the Iraq war movies.” I have just argued that no fictional representations discuss policy. Brian De Palma’s Redacted likely poisoned the well for Packer: The other films (the best known are British filmmaker Nick Broomfield’s Battle for Haditha and Paul Haggis’s In the Valley of Elah) hardly overbalance the 40+ films depicting Americans as innocent but just (or confused, wronged, betrayed) fighting men and women. Packer (2008) fumes about the depiction of
American soldiers as psychopaths who may as well be wearing SS uniforms. The G.I.s rape, burn, and mutilate corpses, torture detainees, accelerate a vehicle to run over a boy playing soccer, wantonly kill civilians and journalists in firefights, humiliate one another, and coolly record their own atrocities for entertainment. Have these things happened in Iraq? Many have. But in the cinematic version of the war, these are the only things that happen in Iraq. (p. 22)

Packer, who labored so successfully in The Assassin’s Gate to produce a balanced account of the nightmare that unfolded in Iraq, should know better. He wants to make sure that the bad news isn’t pinned on the troops, the way it often was in the Vietnam War, when veterans recounted the dreadful receptions to which they returned. When Packer narrates what happens in the films, we should note where and in which texts these actions occur. It may be instructive to revisit his list, then, and make some minor annotations. Once more, here’s Packer (2008):
The G.I.s rape [Redacted, Battle for Haditha], burn [Battle for Haditha], and mutilate corpses [described but not seen in In the Valley of Elah], torture detainees [The Road to Guantanamo, Mark of Cain], accelerate a vehicle to run over a boy playing soccer [In The Valley of Elah], wantonly kill civilians [Redacted, Haditha, The Situation] and journalists in firefights [The Situation], humiliate one another, and coolly record their own atrocities for entertainment [Redacted, In the Valley of Elah]. (p. 22)
On the basis of 5 films, Packer condemns another 45. Perhaps these films stand out because they represent, each of them, events that occurred.

It would be difficult to make a film like The Road to Guantanamo without showing the interrogation and torture of prisoners. It would be impossible to discuss the specific rape, murder, and burning of 15-year-old Abeer Qasim Hamza al-Janabi on March 12, 2006, and the subsequent murder of her father, mother, and 5-year-old sister, if it hadn’t actually happened (“A Soldier’s Shame,” 2006). Equally, The Battle for Haditha would look odd if we removed the reality of the 2005 civilian murders caused by
a group of Marines [who] went on a shooting spree in which 24 Iraqi civilians were killed. Their patrol had been hit by a roadside bomb and one of their comrades was dead. They ordered five men out of a taxi and gunned them down. Then they went into three nearby homes and shot 19 people, including 11 women and children. (Sly, 2011)

As much as Packer might want to focus elsewhere, these films are based on fact. They may have been made into pieces of antiwar or even antisoldier propaganda—De Palma’s Casualties of War (1989) similarly earned him equal measures of loathing and respect for its examination of a comparable event in the Vietnam War). De Palma’s stock in the United States likely fell further when Redacted won the Silver Lion at the 2007 Venice Film Festival, a message from what the Bush White House dubbed “Old Europe” to this “new” America.

If these films drew the American press’s attention while more staid films about soldiers failed at the box office, it suggests what I have been moving toward all along: that the public cannot be made to love a war for long and that these wars have gone hugely filmed but largely unseen. Soldier and deserter Joshua Key had his own response to the daily prosecution of the war, offering a counterpoint to Packer’s impassioned attack on the straw men films he constructs. Key (2007) wonders,
What would happen if every atrocity were compressed into the same day and the same city, still with my eyes watching and my camera at the ready[?] Then, I suspect that the total number of victims would shock and astonish Americans just as profoundly as did the discovery of the My Lai massacre. (p. 217)

The slaughter in Haditha (another one of the soldier-on-civilian stories about which we will probably never know the facts, particularly since thousands of pages of classified reports on the Haditha massacre were found dumped in a Baghdad junkyard; Schmidt, 2011) represents less than a twentieth of the murders in My Lai, but as Key points out, there are lots more to be had (in March 2012, a U.S. Army sergeant walked into a village in Afghanistan where he killed 16 people—including nine children and three women—then burned some of the bodies; Vogt & Khan, 2012). Had a Muslim soldier done the same in America, one can all too well imagine the reaction of the tribute industry that cranked up post-9/11, as well as opinion networks like Fox News). There are many stories from Iraq: Packer is wrong to get irritated about these—they’re true.

The drive to redirect the audience to happier, more conventional narratives about strong men and women who have offered everything they have or, in the endless rhetoric of the post-9/11 years, have made “the ultimate sacrifice,” is fueled by the post-Vietnam rejection of defeat as “inconceivable, so to conceive it is unpatriotic. If a film shows America winning, it is acceptable, even if there are ambiguities over the Army’s motives and the soldiers’ behavior” (Barker, 2011, p. 25). Atrocity films have their own gravitic fields of attraction that draw in the viewer, robbing them of thought and speech. It is precisely expression that is needed when the Geneva Conventions are unilaterally razed, constitutional law is revised to suit White House policies and definitions of torture, and countries can be invaded without the slightest gesture toward jus ad bellum. Ahistorical atrocity films malign thousands of combat troops who acted well only if those films hang in freefall, unattached to events: Hiding war crimes is equally dire, particularly when the offenses at stake are declared to be legally part of a entire war policy, as they have been. The real problem with most atrocity films is not that they exist but that they do so in a fabular universe of good and evil instead of an infinite universe of gray areas: they aren’t tough, subtle, or real enough.

sec.title: Degree 6: Crazily Familiar Vets
sec.p: Of the war films that emerged from, reflected, or mined the Vietnam War, one trope that transferred unaltered to Iraq films is the “crazy” veteran. Played with bug-eyed lunacy by Bruce Dern in Hal Ashby’s 1978 Coming Home, the insane veteran was someone characterized by Michael Herr and Francis Ford Coppola as a kid “from some South Bronx shithole, and I think the light and the space of Vietnam really put the zap on his head” (Apocalypse Now! 2001, 21:37). Over the years they returned from the war, Vietnam vets began appearing in films as another dangerous example of rebellious youth. In Vietnam films like Rolling Thunder (1977), the veteran unmoored from reality is typified by William Devane (with costar Tommy Lee Jones as the even more terrifying empty-faced Master Sergeant Johnny Vohden); in Michael Cimino’s The Deer Hunter (1978) it’s Nick, played by Christopher Walken, who finds peace only by playing Russian roulette each night; in the Rambo series, the veteran remains the only sane being in a world of corruption, betrayal, and hatred of soldiers—for that, he is classified a public enemy and hunted down. The unstable, violent veteran appears in films as diverse as Apocalypse Now! (1979), Birdy (1984), Black Sunday (1977), Cutter’s Way (1981), Distant Thunder (1988), Jacknife (1989), Platoon (1986), The Stunt Man (1980), Taxi Driver (1976), Twilight’s Last Gleaming (1977), When You Comin’ Back, Red Ryder? (1979), Year of the Dragon (1985)—on and on and on. In these films, and particularly before the definition of PTSD began to sharpen and cast into relief what soldiers might be suffering, veterans filled the role of villain or sociopath now taken up by serial murderers or the ingenious sadists running the show in so-called “torture porn” films like the Saw (seven films to date) or Hostel (three films) franchises.

Worry about showing veterans in a bad light has so far kept filmmakers quiet: If George Packer feels aggrieved about five films, he should remember the dozens that used veterans in the post-Vietnam environment for their political grist. Phil Strub, the Pentagon’s film liaison, notes that
“These days, there is an unwillingness to criticize individual servicemen and women, which was quite common in the Vietnam era . . . Americans are very disinclined to do that now, and we’re very glad this attitude tends to pervade all entertainment.” (Soriano & Oldenburg, 2005)

The trope of the crazed veteran has, however, persisted. Despite an enormous increase in education about PTSD, it is still depicted as something that happens to the weak—one exception is Samuel Jackson’s character in Irvin Winkler’s Home of the Brave (2006), a doctor in denial about his own psychological illness. In films like Stop-Loss (2008), while the hero may doubt the war, he is no coward and never considers suicide, unlike the group’s weak link, played by Joseph Gordon Levitt. The soldiers’ heroism is underscored when they choose to return to Iraq—they are strong in their war faith, or certainty in America. The films that fall into the category of unhinged veteran overlap, as most do, with others: Classifying a film inevitably does its subtleties a disservice. Most films operate on multiple planes, even ones that appear (Divergence, Badland) to be reduced to one or two. With those caveats in mind, the films that draw most heavily on the crazed-veteran genre include Badland (2007), Brothers (2009), Essential Killing (2010), G.I. Jesus (2006), Garrison (2008), Home of the Brave (2006), In the Valley of Elah (2007), The Kill Point (2007), Outlaw (2007), some episodes of Over There (2005), Stop-Loss (2008), and Time Bomb (2008).

Some films propose that the returning veteran has been driven insane by war, although the soldiers threaten only themselves, not the community at large. The oddest of these is Time Bomb, in which an addled veteran cannot determine what is real: At the text’s heart is one sure thing—his young son has burned to death in an accident. His guilt about this tragedy coupled with war trauma produces a series of paranoid fantasies, perhaps realities, involving evil civilian scientists who are either using soldiers’ bodies for an organ trade or figuring out how to kill men by causing their self-combustion. If the film is unconvincing, it recalls a number of surreal classics from the American New Wave, particularly Easy Rider (1969), ElectraGlide in Blue (1973), and Vanishing Point (1971)—the intriguing G.I. Jesus (2006) is of the same genre.

Veterans who attack the community are more numerous, exemplified by John Leguizamo’s “Mr. Wolf,” a discharged, decorated sergeant with 15 years of military service who, with his loyal soldiers, stages a robbery at a major downtown bank in Pittsburgh (The Kill Point, 2007). The affair soon deteriorates into a drawn-out hostage debacle. Trapped inside the bank, Mr. Wolf begins negotiating for terms with nonveteran but experienced police captain Horst Cali, played by Donnie Walhberg. The series (it was aired as eight episodes on Spike TV in 2007) follows the predictable relations that develop inside the bank, while the encoded intelligent “good guy” negotiator (he has a pregnant wife, makes sure to shave, corrects other people’s grammar) struggles to find a way to rescue the hostages. Some hostages seem to have been hoping for a bank robbery all their lives, they fall so quickly into the Stockholm syndrome. The center of the piece is a long monologue delivered convincingly by Leguizamo. As with the rest of the series, every gesture rests on some previous film or television moment, particularly Wolf’s speech to the watching crowd, a performance that nearly loses its head nodding to Al Pacino’s famous “Attica” scene in Sidney Lumet’s 1975 Dog Day Afternoon. However, unlike Pacino’s characterization of Sonny Wortzik based on the actual bank robber John Wojtowicz, the fictional Mr. Wolf not only knows SWAT (special weapons and tactics) tactics and hostage-taking protocols, he is a successful military commander who is cool under fire. The text plays a game with both the police captain and the audience: Is Wolf’s real desire to air his political message or to steal money? Although money is Sonny and Sal’s goal in Dog Day Afternoon, the robbery is automatically politicized (especially in the context of 1975) because Wortzik seeks money for a sex change operation. When Mr. Wolf emerges from the bank he takes his case directly to a growing legion of onlookers, and there he makes his stand:
I see you up there, Snipes. I’m lookin’ at you, SWAT. Uniforms. I know what you’re thinking about me, man. I’ve been here before. I’ve had guns pointed at me many times. It’s not new to me, I know the fear. Go ahead. You wanna shoot me? Go ahead, man, shoot me. Go ahead. Look I’ll give you an easy target, man, look, come on [takes off shirt, pants—he’s covered in burn and shrapnel scars] Go ahead, come on. Go ahead. Shoot me. Like they did in Fallujah, man. Or you know what? How about here? How about here, like that shrapnel blast in Baghdad. Go ahead, shoot me. Come on, go ahead [snipers lower their weapons]. What are you waiting for? ‘Cause I love my country, man. I fought for my country and I would die for my country. You think I wanted to end up here? Huh? You think I wanted guns in my face again, man? No way. No freakin’ way. But I came home to sickness and nightmares. You know, when I close my eyes, you know what I see? I see the faces of the soldiers and civilians that I killed, that’s what I see. I spoke to my captain and he makes me talk to a shrink, who doesn’t know shit. And then the goddamn government, smokes me out with their lies and away goes my pension. Away goes my medical. And if my wife gets sick, who’s gonna pay for it, huh? Who’s gonna pay? I pay! [gestures to crowd of onlookers] We pay! I served my country, man. I served—15 years I gave. 15 years! Who’s gonna protect me? Who’s gonna protect me, huh? Who? So I started this and look where I am, man. Look where I am. Back in the firing line. So maybe you should shoot me, go ahead. Maybe you should shoot me. I’d rather die than go to jail, that’s for damn sure. I didn’t spill my blood for this country for freedom, to have it taken away when I came home. I got some demands ‘cause they took everything away from me, okay? I want antibiotics because I’ve got injured in there. And I want a flak jacket for every soldier in Iraq! ‘Cause our stupid-ass government doesn’t think that they’re necessary! And I want the son of every Senator who voted Yes for this war to sign up for active duty. You get me those things, and I’ll leave here. I’ll ask for a bus and a chopper, and I’ll disappear. Got that? [cheering and applause from crowd] [to police Captain] Don’t ever breach again, man. ‘Cause you know what’s at stake and I know how to play. (The Kill Point, 2007, Episode 1, 42:00)

The sergeant’s performance is so sure, so certain, that it impresses the crowd, and the police lose the moral high ground, which has been seized by the war itself, and the attendant injustice of the way the government treats the troops. The sergeant addresses the troops first by specialty and murderousness (the sniper and SWAT teams, both of which are anxious to roll in for a kill), letting them know he “sees them” and understands what they’re capable of, then the regular uniformed officers. He understands them as a tribe, angry with him because a number of them have been killed by his own troops. He constructs the meeting as ritual combat, calling out the enemy to play fair, to level the field, and closes with game imagery. He makes himself completely vulnerable, stripping off his shirt and pants, showings his scars and burns so as to emphasize the degree to which the state has used and discarded his body. For the receptive crowd, what Wolf wants is reasonable: medication for the sick, protection for the fighters, and class equality during wartime service. Wolf’s lecture takes its cues from the famous question Specialist Thomas Wilson posed Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld in 2004, asking, “Why do we soldiers have to dig through local landfills for pieces of scrap metal and compromised ballistic glass to up-armor our vehicles and why don’t we have those resources readily available to us?” (Suarez, 2004). Wolf’s monologue connects the problem of “hillbilly armor” (Raddatz & Cerre, 2004) with the suggestion that elected officials’ offspring should serve, driven home by Michael Moore’s in his Fahrenheit 9/11 (2004).12 What Wolf suggests is hardly a cry against the establishment—rather, it supports it. A career soldier in league with other soldiers, Wolf fights for his own against an enemy (the government) that doesn’t care about or for the little people who do its bidding. The problem is not with the wars in Iraq or Afghanistan, or the irony that while soldiers are treated badly, they are expected to treat enemy combatants worse. Rather, the abuse written in scar tissue on Wolf’s body graphs the problem: Torture is the governing discourse, but the soldiers don’t understand they, too, are its subject.

Unlike Sonny Wortzik’s enraged repetition of the rallying cry “Attica” as he finds himself beset by hordes of uniforms, Wolf calls for a stronger police force. The idea that Wolf isn’t in it just for the money occurs to the SWAT captain in a later episode, when she wonders aloud: “Maybe Wolf’s political agenda isn’t bullshit? And if that’s the case, we’re back to zero.” Her problematic question is capped off by deputy chief Abrami, who lectures her: “Let’s worry about what this means after we get this contained, okay?” (The Kill Point, Episode 5, 12:29) Abrami’s comment speaks to both the hostage taking and war itself: We’ll worry about what we’re doing in Iraq and Afghanistan once it’s “contained,” the kind of vague bureaucratic language that could well mean “once the troops are home,” assuming that means the war is over. Perhaps the bank operates as a larger metaphor for corporate America’s treatment of its soldiers: Like Rambo before them, they must seize control of their own fortunes and hold civilians hostage until the wars can be fought properly. Perhaps Wolf shouldn’t release his hostages until the wars are concluded. While Wolf appears to be the ghost of desperate veterans past, he is truly a model citizen, just as John Rambo was, and is again by the end of the fourth film when he returns to the family farm (Rambo, 2008). The only villains in The Kill Point are greedy ex-soldiers who have become mercenaries. If the film has its crazy veterans, it is also staunchly prosoldier.

Eberwein (2009) argues,
Two of the four major war films of 1978 [Coming Home and The Deer Hunter] . . . accounted for eight Oscars, six in major categories. This suggests something about the anguished mood of the country in regard to the Vietnam War close to the time of US defeat . . . They are in effect the repressed of the Vietnam War, the films that didn’t get made during the conflict. (p. 32)

In the films I group here, the veteran is much more sinned against than sinning—many are utterly at the mercy of external forces, usually civilian bureaucracies that have no sense of obligation toward the men and women who have fought. While some of the soldiers may commit crimes of abuse against their families, they are still shown to have good cause, struggling with what they’ve seen and done. Martin Barker (2011) points out about them, “No matter how crude, misogynistic and racist the soldiers may appear when seen off-duty, the moment they step out onto the streets of Iraq they become innocent, bewildered and desperate” (pp. 32-33): The same is true at home. The soldier is, except as characterized in the films that so gore George Packer’s ox (Battle for Haditha, Redacted, In the Valley of Elah), a sacred individual who remains honored and honorable. Barker continues by noting that the soldiers’ “brutality simply [is] a mistake arising out of stress and sickness” (p. 32). The issue is not a soldier’s guilt but rather the adoption and reversal of the Vietnam film trope. Where Vietnam veterans on film are often detached, amoral killers like Taxi Driver’s Travis Bickle, who understands himself to be “God’s lonely man,” Iraq war veterans on film are in good company and have been befriended, even when they’re not very friendly, by the American public. In a potentially resistant text like The Messenger (2009), what prevents the widow Olivia Pitterson (Samantha Morton) from beginning a relationship with Staff Sergeant Will Montgomery (Ben Foster) is the fact that once her cruel soldier husband is dead, she remembers the man she had fallen in love with, and must mourn him. The audience is given no reason to lament his death: By her account he was abusive to her and her child, hurt, and in pain. Still, the film stands by the soldiers, even the dissolute, troubled Captain Tony Stone (Woody Harrelson), who brings the living news of the dead. Veterans may be dysfunctional, but they are certainly no worse than the aimless, wandering civilians around them.

Among the great myths of the war was the revision of this phrase so that it became: “When you’ve got them by the balls, their hearts and minds will follow.”

In an earlier article, I considered the significance of the coverage of Princess Diana’s death outstripping all news stories published about World War II (Blackmore, 2004, p. 48). The tendency to pay more attention to the slightest move made by a celebrity as opposed to dire worldwide issues like famines or civil wars has been neatly captured by MIT media scholar Ethan Zuckerman (2012), who proposes measuring news coverage in “Kardashians” (the name derives from socialite and reality star Kim Kardashian). Zuckerman compares the relative attention paid by the media to a famine in the Horn of Africa with celebrity Kim Kardashian on any given day. Where the famine flatlines at 1 Kardashian (a high score), Kardashian herself averages 20 Kardashians per day (even Angelina Jolie rates only about 9 Kardashians daily). The infamous Joseph Kony video (100 million views on YouTube) about the Lord’s Resistance Army clocked a mere 7.7 Kardashians at its peak; Kardashian’s announced divorce in October 2011 and June 2012 Oprah appearance each drew 100 Kardashians. As whimsical as such a proposed metric might appear, it is a keen indicator of how serious news issues fare when rated against celebrity events (Zuckerman, 2012).

Remakes are another way for Hollywood to dodge taking chances on new material and often have nothing additional to recommend them except that North American audiences unwilling to read subtitles can have lines spoken aloud for them (a good case in point are the superb Swedish films based on Stieg Larsson’s Girl With the Dragon Tattoo books: Remaking these was an exercise in money, safety, and English).

I am reminded of Vietnam veteran Philip Beidler’s (2004) scathing warning to future veterans:
Go out and do the mission, we’ll say. Deal with the Charlies or the Sammies or the ragheads or whatever. From where I stand, after all these years, I can offer only one sure lesson: Don’t come home remotely expecting anyone to care. (p. 212)

On a side note, it’s hard not to feel that a person in our culture of celebrity who looks like Rachel McAdams would more likely be flying to Hollywood than Iraq. The sheer fact of casting McAdams in the role nearly eradicates her character’s quality of the genuine.

Few passages are as heartbreaking as Bill Ehrhart’s (1995) condemnation of his teenage participation in the war. On reading The Pentagon Papers in 1971, Ehrhart came to the bitter conclusion that for Lyndon Johnson, Robert McNamara, and William Westmoreland, he had
been a fool, ignorant and naïve. A sucker. For such men, I had become a murderer. For such men, I had forfeited my honor, my self-respect, and my humanity. For such men, I had been willing to lay down my life. And I had been nothing more to them than a hired gun, a triggerman, a stooge, a tool to be used and discarded, an insignificant statistic. (p. 175)

The even deeper irony of the biblical parable is that the American military has characterized fourth-generation warfare (4GW) using the David and Goliath narrative as its core example, where rather than have pitched battles between the standing armies of the Warsaw Pact, 4GW forecasts unequal guerilla wars in urban terrain, just like the one fought in Iraq.
A discussion between two of the characters on the train makes it clear that racial profiling will not be tolerated.

The parallel atrocity of widespread rape in the U.S. military has finally received its own documentary, Kirby Dick’s The Invisible War (2012), a problem both officially known about and denied for decades.

It’s worth saying, after all this time, that all the wars America has been involved in have been problematic. World War II is invariably used as an example of “the good war,” as Studs Terkel ironically named it in his 1984 oral history of a war that, it turned out, wasn’t the unified “good” thing people thought it had been. As more narratives emerge, it is increasingly difficult to say that any war is “good” or that it was fought for one reason only. The Vietnam War appeared to end the long narrative of American exceptionalism, but perhaps that was only a bump in the road—a 25-year, 58,000 (American) dead, 2 to 3 million Vietnamese dead, bump.

Given the box office disasters these films (with a few exceptions) represent, and the fact that most documentaries rarely earn back the money it cost to make them, that Michael Moore’s Fahrenheit 9/11 brought in $200 million worldwide indicates where people were looking, and what Hollywood might have tried to do.
